shed.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a small building, often made of wood, used especially for storing things
shed.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a large industrial building where work is done, large vehicles are kept, machinery is stored etc
shed.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to get rid of something that you no longer need or want
shed.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The company is planning to shed about a quarter of its workforce.
The magazine is desperately trying to shed its old-fashioned image.
a diet to help you shed pounds
shed.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if a plant sheds its leaves or if an animal sheds skin or hair, they fall off as part of a natural process
shed.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The trees were starting to shed their leaves.
As it grows, a snake will regularly shed its skin.
shed.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to drop something or allow it to fall
shed.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: He strode across the bathroom, shedding wet clothes as he went.
A lorry shed its load of steel bars on the M25.
shed.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if something sheds water, the water flows off its surface, instead of sinking into it
shed.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: The bank continued to shed workers.
Doing exercise is the best way to shed surplus weight.
I needed to shed a few pounds.
Has the industry finally shed its negative image?
As the party went on, people began to shed their inhibitions.
shed.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to get rid of something that you no longer need, especially workers
shed.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Plans to shed another 10,000 employees were unveiled.
There are companies who are making high levels of profit and who are still shedding jobs.
shed.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if shares shed an amount they become less in value by that amount
shed.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The shares shed 55 cents to close at A$15.9.
